customer_name: CJ's Great Cats World Park Inc
site_name: CJ's Great Cats World Park Inc

citations.narrative:
Records for animals on hand and acquisition/disposition of animals were incomplete. The licensee did not have an
acquisition record for or include in the Record of Animals on Hand two servals that were being exhibited and a litter of four
servals that were born at the facility. The licensee did not make or keep a disposition record for a serval . Appropriate
documentation on Acquisition and Disposition of regulated animals, as well as a Record of Animals on Hand, is essential
for proper identification and to ensure the humane treatment of animals.
The licensee must make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in
possession and control of or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by the exhibitor. These
records need to include the offspring born of any animal on the property.
Correct by 12 September 2025.

There is about a 20- to 30-foot-wide open gap without any perimeter fence on the northwest section of the facility. This
gap is at the southwest corner of the hay storage barn to the end of the fence dividing the parking lot from the zoo
grounds. The perimeter fence must be maintained so that it functions as a secondary containment system for the animals
in the facility. Correct by ensuring the fence meets the requirement of being 8 feet high in all areas and serves as
secondary containment.
Correct by September 30, 2025.

The horse meat in the food prep room was covered with multiple round cottony formations consistent with mold growth.
Moldy meat is contaminated and not safe to feed the animals. Correct by ensuring food fed to the animals is wholesome,
palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in good health.
Corrected at the time of inspection.

A significant accumulation of debris, unused fencing, corrugated sheathing, and unused crates are amassed in close
proximity to the food preparation area and up against the perimeter fence. Lack of housekeeping and sanitation attracts
pests into the facility, resulting in unpleasant odors, and may contribute to the spread of disease. Accumulations of debris
can also provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests and could increase health risks to the animals.
Correct by ensuring that premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean, in good repair and accumulations of trash are
placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary in order to protect the animals from injury, protect their health, and
to facilitate prescribed husbandry practices.
Correct by 22 September 2025

Rodent feces was observed on top of the water heater and on the floor behind the water heater in the food prep room.
Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster
the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. The facility must ensure that a safe and effective program for the
control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests is established and maintained.
Corrected at the time of inspection 27 August 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Gustavo Soberano, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
AMY JIRSA-SMITH, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOREnd Section

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Records for animals on hand and acquisition/disposition of animals were incomplete. The licensee did not have an 
acquisition record for or include in the Record of Animals on Hand two servals that were being exhibited and a litter of four 
servals that were born at the facility. The licensee did not make or keep a disposition record for a serval . Appropriate 
documentation on Acquisition and Disposition of regulated animals, as well as a Record of Animals on Hand, is essential 
for proper identification and to ensure the humane treatment of animals.  
The licensee must make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in 
possession and control of or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by the exhibitor. These 
records need to include the offspring born of any animal on the property.  
Correct by 12 September 2025. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is about a 20- to 30-foot-wide open gap without any perimeter fence on the northwest section of the facility. This 
gap is at the southwest corner of the hay storage barn to the end of the fence dividing the parking lot from the zoo 
grounds. The perimeter fence must be maintained so that it functions as a secondary containment system for the animals 
in the facility. Correct by ensuring the fence meets the requirement of being 8 feet high in all areas and serves as 
secondary containment.  
Correct by September 30, 2025. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
The horse meat in the food prep room was covered with multiple round cottony formations consistent with mold growth. 
Moldy meat is contaminated and not safe to feed the animals. Correct by ensuring food fed to the animals is wholesome, 
palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in good health.  
Corrected at the time of inspection. 
3.131(c)

Sanitation. 
A significant accumulation of debris, unused fencing, corrugated sheathing, and unused crates are amassed in close 
proximity to the food preparation area and up against the perimeter fence. Lack of housekeeping and sanitation attracts 
pests into the facility, resulting in unpleasant odors, and may contribute to the spread of disease. Accumulations of debris 
can also provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests and could increase health risks to the animals. 
Correct by ensuring that premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean, in good repair and accumulations of trash are 
placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary in order to protect the animals from injury, protect their health, and 
to facilitate prescribed husbandry practices.  
Correct by 22 September 2025 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
Rodent feces was observed on top of the water heater and on the floor behind the water heater in the food prep room. 
Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster 
the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. The facility must ensure that a safe and effective program for the 
control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests is established and maintained.  
Corrected at the time of inspection 27 August 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Gustavo Soberano, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
AMY JIRSA-SMITH, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOREnd Section
